sen.j: 拝舞（はいぶ、はいむ）は、平安時代、宮中で、叙位、任官、賜禄の際などに、謝意を表して左右左(さゆうさ)を行う礼である。
sen.e: Haibu (pronounced as hai-bu or hai-mu) refers to a ritual of bowing which performs sayusa (a series of movement to the left, right, and left) for expressing his or her gratitude on occasions such as joi (investiture of a Court rank), appointment, and shiroku (receiving a stipend) in the Imperial Court in Heian period.

sen.j: 『世俗浅深秘抄』によれば、朝覲行幸のとき天皇は左右左、臣下は右左右であったのが、のちに変じて、天皇は右左右、臣下は左右左となったという。
sen.e: According to "Sezoku senshin hi sho" (a ceremonial rule book written by the Emperor Gotoba), originally the Emperor performed sayusa (left-right-left) and retainers performed usayu (right-left-right) in the event of Chokin no Gyoko (New Year's visit to the Imperial Palace), and later the manners changed: the Emperor did usayu, retainers did sayusa.
